Catalysis of core-shell nanoparticle M@Pt (MCo and Ni) for oxygen reduction reaction and its electronic structure in comparison to Pt nanoparticle Bo Zhu a Jing Lu b Shigeyoshi Sakaki a ⁎ a Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, 1-30 Goryo-Ohara, Nishikyo-ku, Kyoto 615-8245, Japan Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB) Kyoto University 1-30 Goryo-Ohara Nishikyo-ku Kyoto 615-8245 Japan Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts and Batteries (ESICB), Kyoto University, 1-30 Goryo-Ohara, Nishikyo-ku, Kyoto 615-8245, Japan b Fukui Institute for Fundamental Chemistry (FIFC), Kyoto University, Takano-Nishihiraki-cho 34-4, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8103, Japan Fukui Institute for Fundamental Chemistry (FIFC) Kyoto University Takano-Nishihiraki-cho 34-4 Sakyo-ku Kyoto 606-8103 Japan Fukui Institute for Fundamental Chemistry (FIFC), Kyoto University, Takano-Nishihiraki-cho 34-4, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8103, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This work clearly disclosed that the lower energy d-valence band-top of M13@Pt42 is the origin of the higher activity of the M13@Pt42, which arises from the smaller exchange repulsion of the Pt42 shell with the M13 core than with the Pt13 core. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) by Pt55 and core-shell M13@Pt42 (MCo or Ni) particles is explored theoretically. Rate-determining step (RDS) is the second OH formation in M13@Pt42 but the second H2O formation in Pt55. Activation energy of RDS decreases following the order Pt55 > Co13@Pt42 > Ni13@Pt42 and onset potential is larger in M13@Pt42 than in Pt55, showing M13@Pt42 is more active than Pt55. Lower energy d-valence band-top (φVB-top) of M13@Pt42 results in the higher activity of M13@Pt42 than that of Pt55, where φVB-top is the highest energy peak in d-valence band DOS. Thus, the φVB-top energy is important for ORR activity. The lower energy φVB-top of M13@Pt42 than that of Pt55 mainly arises from smaller exchange repulsion of Pt42 shell with M13 core than that with Pt13 core; smaller atomic size and d orbital size of Co and Ni than those of Pt are key factors. Keywords Core-shell nanoparticle Oxygen reduction reaction DFT d-Valence band Ni-Pt core-shell nanoparticle Co-Pt core-shell nanoparticle Pt nanoparticle 1 Introduction Pt-based core-shell nanoparticle (Mm@Ptn) consisting of low-cost abundant Mm core and precise Ptn shell (m, n = appropriate integer number, which will be omitted hereinafter for brevity) is one of important and interesting nanoparticles in the chemistry of metal particles because Pt content can be reduced in the nanoparticle without losing catalytic activity of Pt particle, as reviewed recently [1–3]. Also, the core-shell nanoparticle is expected to become a better catalyst than pure Pt particle because the reactivity and the electronic structure of the Pt shell can be turned by using appropriate M core [4]. Actually, many core-shell M@Pt nanoparticles have been applied to cathode electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC), as discussed by recent reviews [5–10] and many recent works [11–27] (even after the recent review ref. 6). Good examples are Ni@Pt and Co@Pt nanoparticles which exhibit higher catalytic activity for ORR than pure Pt particle [11,18,21–24,27–36]. These experimental results indicate that the Ni and Co cores improve reactivity and catalytic activity of the Pt shell. Because the Pt-based nanoparticle is one of promising cathode catalysts for ORR, it is worthy of elucidating the reason(s) why Co@Pt and Ni@Pt nanoparticles are more active than Pt particle on the basis of their electronic structures. The ORR catalytic activity of M@Pt has been discussed on the basis of binding energies of such oxygen-containing intermediates as O2, O and OH species with the Pt surface in theoretical studies [37–55]. Many of them explained the binding energies on the basis of d-band model [41–47,50–53]. On the other hand, Pathak and co-workers reported that the d-band model was not useful for explaining higher ORR activity of Ti19@Pt60 than that of Pt79 particle but ligand effect and charge transfer (CT) were useful for understanding catalysis of Ti19@Pt60 [48]. Also, Linic and Xin discussed that the d-band model was not useful for explaining OH, F and Cl adsorptions in the case of d9 or d10 metal surfaces [56]. Thus, we address three important open questions: (i) whether the d-band model is useful or not, (ii) what is an important electronic structure property for determining the ORR catalytic activity of core-shell M@Pt nanoparticle and (iii) what kind of M element enhances the ORR catalytic activity of M@Pt. The knowledge of relation between ORR catalytic activity and electronic structure property of metal nanoparticle is crucially important in the chemistry of nanoscale metal particle. For obtaining the aforementioned relation, we need the correct knowledge of reaction mechanism, rate-determining step (RDS) and electronic process of important elementary steps of ORR. However, catalytic cycle of ORR has not been theoretically investigated well except for several pioneering works [39,57], though O2 adsorption and OO bond cleavage have been investigated by many theoretical works [50–58]. Also, it is not clear what perturbation the M core provides to the electronic structure and the reactivity of the Pt shell of M@Pt nanoparticle. This is the forth important open question. Hence, comprehensive understanding of differences in electronic structure and reactivity between M@Pt and Pt nanoparticles must be elucidated on the basis of theoretical and computational studies. However, theoretical and computational studies of M@Pt nanoparticle have been limited; a few of theoretical studies with DFT calculation reported geometries, stabilities and electronic structures of Ti@Pt [41], Fe@Ni and its reverse combination (Ni@Fe) [59], M@Cu (M = Ru, Rh, Pd, Os, Ir or Pt) [60] and Ni@Pt [61] nanoparticles. In this work, we theoretically investigated ORR catalysis and electronic structure of M@Pt (MCo and Ni) nanoparticles in comparison with those of pure Pt nanoparticle using DFT calculations. Our purposes here are to elucidate reaction mechanism and RDS of ORR by M@Pt and Pt nanoparticles, compare catalysis between M@Pt and Pt nanoparticles, find relation(s) between electronic structure property and ORR activity of these nanoparticles and unveil the reason(s) why M@Pt is more active for ORR than Pt nanoparticle. These theoretical findings are useful for understanding the ORR catalysis of the core-shell M@Pt nanoparticle, finding a better M@Pt nanoparticle for ORR electrocatalyst and making further development of the chemistry of nanoparticles. 2 Computational details 2.1 Method Spin-polarized periodic DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.4.1) [62,63]. The generalized gradient approximation Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) [64] functional was employed in these calculations, where the Grimme’s “D3” dispersion correction was added [65,66]. Plane wave basis sets were used for valence electrons with an energy cutoff of 450 eV after test calculations; see Table S1 in the Supporting Information (SI) for the test calculations. The projector-augmented-wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [67,68] were used for representing core electrons. Energies of density of states (DOS) were evaluated using the HSE06 functional [69], because this hybrid functional is better for calculating band-gap energy than GGA-type functional; in HSE06 calculations, the PBE-D3 optimized geometries were employed. Pt and M@Pt (MCo and Ni) particles were placed at the center of 25 × 25 × 25 Å3 cubic box to avoid interference from its periodic image. A 1 × 1 × 1 k-point mesh and a Gaussian smearing of 0.1 eV were used; see Table S2 in the SI for details. Geometry optimization was performed with threshold of 0.01 eV/Å for force. For calculations of H2, O2 and H2O molecules, the same energy cutoff (450 eV) and cubic box (25 × 25 × 25 Å3) were employed. Transition state was searched using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [70,71] with threshold of 0.2 eV/Å for force. Then, the geometry obtained by the above procedure was further refined using the dimer method [72,73] until the maximum force became smaller than 0.03 eV/Å. We evaluated vibrational frequencies to check if stationary structure does not have any imaginary frequency and transition state has only one imaginary frequency. All species were discussed at the lowest energy spin state. The solvent effects of water (εb = 80, nc = 0.0025 Å−3, σ = 0.6, and τ = 0.525 meV/Å2) were taken into calculation using the implicit solvation model implemented in VASPsol, where the cavitation energy is involved [74,75]. 2.2 Models We employed sub-nanoscale metal particles with 55 metal atoms, Pt55 and M13@Pt42 (MCo and Ni) as a model catalyst in this work, considering that 55-atom particles have been employed as a model catalyst in theoretical studies of many catalytic reactions [41,55,59,61,76–86]. However, we must always remember that 55-atom particles are considerably smaller than real catalysts. Here, we compared the binding energies (E b) of oxygen-containing species (O, O2, OH, and H2O) to Pt55 and M13@Pt42 with those to Pt(1 1 1) surface and extended Pt(1 1 1) surface on either Ni(1 1 1) or Co(0 0 0 1) and found that their binding energies with the 55-atom particles are larger than those with the extended surfaces but the binding energies with the 55-atom particles are mostly parallel to those with the extended surfaces except for a few species, as shown in Figure S1 and Table S5 the SI; discussion is presented below Figure S1 and Table S5. Also, we compared several reaction energies related to ORR between the 55-atom particle and the extended surface in Figure S2 of the SI and found that the smallest reaction energy, which corresponds to thermodynamically limiting step, differs between the 55-atom particle and the extended surface, but the reaction energies (Figure S2) show that the trend of the ORR activity is the same between the 55-atom particle and the extended surface. From these results, we have to be careful for the possibility that the 55-atom particle gives different results on thermodynamically limiting step from the extended surface, as discussed in pages S7-S9 of the SI. As well known, both icosahedral and cuboctahedral structures are possible for 55-atom particle. In this work, we employed the icosahedral structure because the icosahedral Pt55 is calculated to be more stable than the cuboctahedral Pt55 [87]. As shown in Scheme 1 , the icosahedral Pt55 and M13@Pt42 consist of 13 Pt or 13 M atoms for the core and 42 Pt atoms for the shell. The Pt42 shell has twenty (1 1 1) facets, where each (1 1 1) facet possesses two kinds of atom positions such as vertex and edge (Scheme 1). Considering the presence of the vertex and edge positions and three possibilities of on-top, bridging and hollow adsorption structures, we investigated such six adsorption sites on one (1 1 1) facet as on-top#1 (t1) at the vertex, on-top#2 (t2) at the edge, bridge#1 (b1) at the vertex-edge, bridge#2 (b2) at the edge-edge, fcc at the 3-fold-hollow (h1) and hcp at the 3-fold-hollow (h2), where in parenthesis is an abbreviation name. Geometries of M13@Pt42 and Pt55 particles were fully optimized under I h symmetry, while geometries of intermediates and transition states bearing substrate on surface were fully optimized starting from the I h-like geometry without constraint. 2.3 Evaluation of the Gibbs free energy changes The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) was evaluated using the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) model developed by Nørskov and co-workers [88–90]. In this model, the chemical potential (μ) of the proton-electron pair was derived as half of a hydrogen molecule, μ(H+) + μ(e−) = 1/2μ(H2), when the potential applied to electrode (U) is 0 V relative to RHE under standard atmospheric pressure (P(H2) = 1 bar). The chemical potential of each adsorbate is defined, as follows: (1) μ = E + E ZPS - T S ° where E is the total energy obtained from DFT calculation, E ZPE is zeropoint energy and S° is entropy at 298 K. For each elementary step, the ΔG° is defined as the change of the Gibbs free energy when going from initial to final states, using the following Eq. (2): (2) Δ G ° = Δ E + Δ E ZPS - T Δ S ° where Δ E , Δ E ZPE and ΔS° are changes of total energy obtained from DFT calculations, zero-point energy and entropy, respectively, when going from initial to final states. Zero-point energy and entropy were obtained from vibrational frequency computation. Here, entropy of isolated molecule is evaluated by considering vibration, rotation, and translation movements under ideal-gas assumption, while that of adsorbed species is evaluated by considering only vibration movements. The bias effect ( Δ G U ) on the free energy change of each step involving electron transfer is taken into account by shifting the energy of the state using Δ G U = - n e U , where n is the number of transferred electrons (e) and U is the potential (relative to RHE) applied to electrode as mentioned above. Throughout this work, ΔG° at 298 K is presented. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Possible elementary steps in ORR Prior to starting detailed discussion, we will briefly discuss plausible elementary steps in ORR on metal particle. As shown in Scheme 2 , the first step is O2 adsorption to metal particle (step i) followed by either the OO bond cleavage to afford an (O)2 adsorbed species 3a (step ii-a) or H+/e− addition to afford an (O2)(H) species 3b (step ii-b). In the next step, 3a undergoes H+/e− addition to metal surface to afford an (O)2(H) species 4a (step iii-a). On the other hand, 3b undergoes either OO bond cleavage to afford the (O)2(H) species 4a (step iii-b) or reaction between O2 and H to afford an OOH species 4b (step iii-c). Starting from 4a, the H reacts with one of the two O atoms to afford an (O)(OH) species 5a (step iv-a). Starting from 4b, the OOH bond cleavage occurs to afford 5a (step iv-b). The other elementary step starting from 4b is H+/e− addition (step iv-c) followed by H2O2 formation 6b (step v-b). After 5a undergoes H+/e− addition to afford an (O)(OH)(H) species 6a (step v-a), either an (O)(H2O) species 7a or an (OH)2 species 7b is formed (step vi-a or vi-b, respectively). Starting from 7a, H2O dissociates from the metal surface with H+/e− addition to afford an (O)(H) species 8a (step vii-a). In 8a, the O atom reacts with the H to afford an OH species 9 on the surface (step viii-a). In the alternative reaction course, 7b undergoes H+/e− addition to afford an (OH)(OH)(H) species 8b#1 (step vii-b). Then, the H reacts with one of the two OH groups to yield a (H2O)(OH) species 8b#2 (step viii-b). Starting from 8b#2, H2O dissociation occurs to afford an OH species 9 (step viii-c). H+/e− addition to 9 yields a (H)(OH) species 10 (step ix). The last step is the reaction between the H and the OH in 10 leading to the second H2O formation with regeneration of metal particle (step x). Here, we wish to mention that we have to consider two plausible pathways about the H+/e− addition; one is H+/e− addition to the Pt surface (Langmuir-Hinshelwood pathway) and the other is H+/e− addition to adsorbed O2 molecule (Eley-Rideal pathway). However, it is very difficult to elucidate which occurs more easily because this is proton-coupled electron transfer and solvation change is significantly large. This issue remains as one important open question even nowadays; see also additional discussion presented in page S13 of the SI on the basis of several theoretical works on this open question [89,91,92]. Here, we will investigate first the H+/e− addition to the Pt surface as elementary step, considering that several theoretical works investigated this step in the catalytic cycle of ORR [93,94]. Then, we will present discussion of ORR activity when H+/e− addition occurs to oxygen-containing species adsorbed to the metal particle surface, in Section 3.5. We will explore all these elementary steps on M13@Pt42 to find the most favorable ORR mechanism from kinetic and thermodynamic viewpoints. Then, we will discuss reaction mechanism, rate-determining step (RDS), onset potential, catalytic activity and comparison between M13@Pt42 and Pt55, where the elementary step with the largest activation energy is named RDS for convenience hereinafter; note that the RDS here is no more than one of kinetically significant steps, strictly speaking, because microkinetic analysis was not performed. Next, we will clarify the electronic process of RDS and try to find what property of these metal particles determines the activation barrier of RDS. Lastly, we will inspect into electronic structures of Pt55 and M13@Pt42 and elucidate the reason(s) why M13@Pt42 is more active than Pt55. 3.2 ORR by Ni13@Pt42 Firstly, we will discuss all the possible elementary steps of the ORR by Ni13@Pt42. 3.2.1 O2 adsorption, OO bond cleavage and (O)(OH) formation O2 adsorption to Ni13@Pt42 firstly occurs to afford an (O2) adsorbed species 2Ni . We investigated six possible adsorption sites and four adsorption modes (η1 (4), η2 (2), μ2 (2) and μ3 (2)), as shown in Scheme 1. The most stable is O2 adsorption at the b1 site in a μ2 manner ((O2)/b1, 2Ni ); see Figure S3 in the SI. As shown in Fig. 1 , this adsorption is exergonic of 1.00 eV. Starting from 2Ni , two possible reaction courses were investigated. In one, OO bond cleavage occurs via a transition state TS2/3aNi to afford an (O)2/h2h2 species 3aNi (black line in Fig. 1). In TS2/3aNi , the O1 O2 and Pt1 Pt2 bonds are elongated to 1.990 Å and 3.269 Å from 1.384 Å and 2.706 Å in 2Ni , respectively, while the Pt1 O1 and Pt2 O2 bonds become shorter to 1.799 Å and 1.798 Å from 1.994 Å and 2.004 Å in 2Ni . The Gibbs activation energy (ΔG° ‡) and Gibbs reaction energy (ΔG°) of this OO bond cleavage are 0.38 eV and −0.20 eV, respectively. The other plausible reaction is H+/e− addition (H1) to Pt surface of 2Ni to form an (O2)(H)/b1t2 species 3bNi , as discussed above. Starting from 3bNi , OO bond cleavage occurs via a transition state TS3/4aNi to afford an (O1)(O2)(H1)/h2h2b1 species 4aNi . In TS3/4aNi , the O1 O2 and Pt1 Pt2 distances are considerably elongated to 1.967 Å and 3.210 Å from 1.381 Å and 2.706 Å in 3bNi , respectively. The ΔG° ‡ is moderate (0.45 eV). Starting from 4aNi , the H1 reacts with the O1 via a transition state TS4/5aNi to afford an (O2)(O1H1)/h2t1 species 5a#2Ni with ΔG° ‡ of 0.60 eV (red line in Fig. 1). In the other reaction course starting from 3bNi (blue line in Fig. 1), the OOH species 4bNi is produced by reaction between the H1 and the O2 via a transition state TS3/4bNi with ΔG° ‡ of 0.66 eV. Subsequently, the OOH bond cleavage occurs via a transition state TS4/5bNi with nearly no barrier, to afford (O)(OH) species 5a#1 Ni ; note 5a#1 Ni is less stable than 5a#2 Ni because the O is adsorbed at the on-top of Pt in 5a#1 Ni but at the hollow site in 5a#2 Ni . Because TS3/4aNi for the (O2)(H) → (O)2(H) step is at lower energy than TS3/4bNi for the (O2)(H) → (OOH) step, the OO bond cleavage of O2 in the presence of H more easily occurs than the OOH formation followed by OOH bond cleavage. In summary, the (O)(OH) 5a#2 Ni species is produced through the OO bond cleavage of the (O2)(H) species 3bNi followed by OH formation, 1Ni → (O2) 2Ni → (O2)(H) 3bNi → (O)2(H) 4aNi → (O)(OH) 5a#2Ni . The formation of (OOH) species 4bNi needs a larger ΔG° ‡ (0.66 eV) than that for OO bond cleavage (ΔG° ‡ = 0.45 eV) in the Ni13@Pt42 case, indicating that H2O2 formation is ruled out in this ORR; see Figure S4 in the SI. 3.2.2 The first H2O formation For H2O formation, 5a#2Ni needs one more H atom. As shown in Fig. 2 , H+/e− (H2) addition to 5a#2Ni occurs at the b1 site neighboring to OH to afford an (O2)(O1H)(H2)/h2t1b1 species 6aNi with ΔG° = −0.24 eV relative to 5a#2Ni . Then, the first H2O is produced via two possible reaction courses from 6aNi . In one, the H2 reacts with the O1H via a transition state TS6/7aNi to form an (O2)(H2O1)/h2t1 species 7aNi with ΔG° ‡ = 0.44 eV. This 7aNi undergoes H2O dissociation followed by H+/e− (H3) addition to afford an (O2)(H3)/h2b1 species 8a#1Ni with ΔG° = −0.30 eV, as shown by a red line in Fig. 2. In the other course, the H2 reacts with the O2 via a transition state TS6/7bNi to afford an (OH)2/b1t1 species 7bNi with larger ΔG° ‡ (0.58 eV) than that for TS6/7aNi and moderate exergonicity (ΔG° = −0.69 eV), as shown by a blue line in Fig. 2 [95]. Subsequently, 7bNi undergoes H+/e− (H3) addition to afford an (OH)2(H3)/b1t1b1 species 8b#1Ni with ΔG° = −0.25 eV. Then, the H3 reacts with one O1H group to yield an (OH)(H2O)/b1t1 species 8b#2Ni via a transition state TS8b#1/#2Ni with moderate ΔG° ‡ (0.50 eV) and moderate exergonicity (ΔG° = −0.27 eV). Because TS6/7aNi exists at lower energy than TS6/7bNi (Fig. 2), it is concluded that the first H2O molecule is formed from the (O2)(O1H)(H2)/h2t1b1 species 6aNi via the reaction between H2 and O1H (6aNi → 7aNi → 8a#1Ni ) with moderate ΔG° ‡ (0.44 eV). 3.2.3 The second H2O formation Starting from the (O2)(H3)/b1t1 species 8a#1Ni , the H3 moves to another b1 site neighboring to the O2 to afford 8a#2Ni with marginal energy change (ΔG° = 0.07 eV), as shown in Fig. 3 . Then, the H3 reacts with the O2 via a transition state TS8/9Ni to form an (O2H3)/t1 species 9Ni with ΔG° ‡ of 0.66 eV. Subsequently, 9Ni undergoes H+/e− (H4) addition to form (O2H3)(H4)/t1b1 species 10#1Ni . In 10#1Ni , the H4 is too distant from the O2H3 to participate in H2O formation. The H4 migrates to other b1 site neighboring to the O2H3 group with moderate endergonicity (ΔG° = 0.19 eV) to afford another (O2H3)(H4)/t1b1 species 10#2Ni . In 10#2Ni , the H4 reacts with the O2H3 via a transition state TS10/11Ni to afford an H2O/t1 species 11Ni with moderate ΔG° ‡ (0.59 eV) and negative ΔG° (−0.24 eV) relative to 10#1Ni . This ΔG° ‡ is smaller than those for TS4/5aNi ((O)(OH) formation; ΔG° ‡ = 0.60 eV) and TS8/9Ni (the second OH formation; ΔG° ‡ = 0.66 eV). These ΔG° ‡ values lead to the conclusion that RDS is not the second H2O formation but the first and the second OH formations (TS4/5Ni and TS8/9Ni ) in the ORR by Ni13@Pt42; since ΔG° ‡ value for TS8/9Ni is moderately larger than that for TS4/5aNi , we will employ the ΔG° ‡ value for TS8/9Ni in discussing the ORR activity of Ni13@Pt42 hereinafter. In summary, the most favorable ORR catalytic cycle by Ni13@Pt42 consists of O2 adsorption, the first H+/e− addition to the Pt surface, OO bond cleavage, (O)(OH) formation (the first OH formation), the second H+/e− addition, the first H2O formation, the H2O dissociation with the third H+/e− addition, the second OH formation, the forth H+/e− addition and the second H2O formation, as shown in Scheme 3 , where RDS is the second OH formation. 3.3 ORR by Co13@Pt42 Here, we will focus on the most favorable reaction course to avoid similar discussion. As shown in Fig. 4 and Scheme 3, the ORR catalytic cycle by Co13@Pt42 is the same as that by Ni13@Pt42; all possible reaction courses in the first step and the first H2O formation were investigated in Figure S6 of the SI, which indicates that the reaction course of Fig. 4 is the most favorable, as discussed in page S11 of the SI. The second OH formation (ΔG° ‡ = 0.80 eV) is RDS in the Co13@Pt42 case, but it is larger than that (ΔG° ‡ = 0.66 eV) of the second OH formation (RDS) in the Ni13@Pt42 case. 3.4 ORR by Pt55 and its comparison with ORR by Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 To explore whether M13@Pt42 (MCo and Ni) is more active for ORR than Pt55 or not, we similarly investigated the most favorable reaction courses of ORR by Pt55, as shown in Fig. 5 and Scheme 3. The elementary steps in the most favorable ORR catalytic cycle by Pt55 are the same as those by Ni13@Pt42; all possible reaction courses of the first step were investigated in Figure S6, which shows that the first step in Fig. 5 is the most favorable; see page S11 of the SI. However, it should be noted that RDS is not the second OH formation but the second H2O formation and its ΔG° ‡ value is considerably large (1.10 eV). This ΔG° ‡ value is much larger than those of RDSs in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 cases. In summary, several interesting differences are found among Ni13@Pt42, Co13@Pt42 and Pt55, as follows: (i) RDS is the second OH formation from O and H species in ORR by Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 but the second H2O formation from OH and H species in ORR by Pt55. (ii) The ΔG° ‡ for the second OH formation does not differ very much among Pt55 (0.88 eV), Ni13@Pt42 (0.66 eV) and Co13@Pt42 (0.80 eV), where in parenthesis is the ΔG° ‡ value. (iii) The second H2O formation occurs much more easily on Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than on Pt55, indicating that the Ni13 and Co13 cores of Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 accelerate the second H2O formation compared with the Pt13 core in Pt55. The reason(s) will be discussed below. 3.5 Effects of potential on the Gibbs free energy changes in ORR by Pt55, Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 and comparison of their ORR activity when H+/e− attacks adsorbed OH Fig. 6 shows the Gibbs free energy changes calculated for the ORR by Pt55, Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42. All the elementary steps occur spontaneously at U = 0 V (RHE) in Pt55, Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 because of ΔG° < 0 for all steps (black line in Fig. 6). Since the Gibbs energy change in the Pt55 case is −0.87 eV, −0.56 eV, −0.56 eV and −0.54 eV at each of four electron transfer steps, respectively, at U = 0 V (RHE), the Gibbs energy change of the second H2O formation ((OH) + H+/e− → H2O) becomes zero when U is 0.54 V (RHE, red line in Fig. 6a) but negative (downhill) for other steps even in this case, indicating that the thermodynamically limiting step is the second H2O formation in the Pt55 case. Also in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42, the second H2O formation occurs with the least negative Gibbs energy change (Fig. 6b and 6c), indicating that the second H2O formation is thermodynamically limiting step. Fig. 6b and 6c show that the onset potential is 0.59 V and 0.68 V for Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42, respectively, which are higher than that for Pt55. These computational results agree with the experimental results showing that Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 are more active than Pt55 [22,28]. If not the H+/e− addition to the Pt surface but that to OH species adsorbed on the Pt surface occurs in the ORR, the second H2O formation from the (OH)(H) species is not involved in the reaction. Even in such case, Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 are better catalyst than Pt55 because their onset potentials are larger than that of Pt55, indicating that Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 are better than Pt55 as electrode catalyst. This feature arises from the more negative ΔG° for this step in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than in Pt55. Thus, it should be concluded that the better ORR performance of Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than that of Pt55 arises from significant acceleration of the second H2O formation by these core-shell particles both kinetically and thermodynamically. The next important task is to elucidate the reason(s) why the second H2O formation occurs with smaller ΔG°‡ and more negative ΔG° in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than in Pt55. 3.6 Electronic process of the second H2O formation To find the reason why the second H2O formation is accelerated by the Ni13 and Co13 cores, we need to elucidate the electronic process of the second H2O formation. As shown in Table 1 , the H4 positive charge somewhat increases when going from 10#1 to TS10/11 and increases very much when going from TS10/11 to 11, where the Bader charges are presented. The OH negative charge marginally changes when going from 10#1 to TS10/11 but considerably increases when going from TS10/11 to 11. The positive charge of metal particle decreases as going from 10#1 to 11 and finally the metal particle is negatively charged in 11 in all these reaction systems. These changes in atomic charge lead us to the understanding that the charge-transfer (CT) mainly occurs from the H4 to the metal particle as going from 10#1 to 11 and in addition CT occurs from the H4 to OH as going from TS10/11 to 11. To receive electron density from the H4, it is likely that the d-conduction band-bottom (φCB-btm) of metal particle plays an important role, where the φCB-btm is defined as the lowest energy peak in the d-conduction band DOS and its energy level is represented by ε CB-btm. These changes in charge and the role of the conduction band-bottom are essentially the same as those of reductive elimination in organometallic chemistry [96]. As shown in Fig. 7 (A–C), the εCB-btm of the Pt42 shell, which is the energy level of φCB-btm, was calculated by the HSE06 functional at −4.07 eV, −4.21 eV and −4.44 eV in Pt55(OH)(H), Co13@Pt42(OH)(H) and Ni13@Pt42(OH)(H), respectively [97]. In the Pt55 case, the CT must occur from the H4 to the higher energy φCB-btm, whereas in the Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 the CT occurs to the lower energy φCB-btm. Consequently, both Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 more easily receive electron density from the H species than does Pt55 and the second H2O formation more easily occurs on Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 than on Pt55. It should be concluded that the lower energy φCB-btm of Co13@Pt42(OH)(H) and Ni13@Pt42(OH)(H) than that of Pt55(OH)(H) is one of important properties for accelerating the second H2O formation on Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 compared to that on Pt55. 3.7 Reason(s) why d-valence band-top (φVB-top) of M13@Pt42 (MCo and Ni) exists at lower energy than that of Pt55 Because the φCB-btm of the Pt42 shell in Pt55(OH)(H), Co13@Pt42(OH)(H) and Ni13@Pt42(OH)(H) receives electron density from the H species in the second H2O formation, it is likely that the φCB-btm in these particles becomes to the d-valence band-top orbital (φVB-top) of the Pt42 shell in Pt55, Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42, where the φVB-top is defined as the highest energy peak of the d-valence band DOS of the Pt42 shell and its energy level is represented by εVB-top hereinafter. The d-band center was also evaluated here, as shown in Fig. 7, using the Pt42 shell because the substrate interacts with various sites of the Pt42 shell. The lower energy φCB-btm of Co13@Pt42(OH)(H) and Ni13@Pt42(OH)(H) than that of Pt55(OH)(H) corresponds to the lower energy φVB-top of Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 than that of Pt55. Indeed, the d-valence band-top energy εVB-top (α; −4.95 eV, β; −4.89 eV) of the Pt42 shell is higher in Pt55 than in Co13@Pt42 (α; −5.01 eV, β; −4.96 eV) and Ni13@Pt42 (α; −5.08 eV, β; −5.25 eV), as shown in Fig. 7(D-F), like the lower energy φCB-btm in Co13@Pt42(OH)(H) and Ni13@Pt42(OH)(H) than in Pt55(OH)(H) (Fig. 7(A-C)); it is mentioned that the PBE functional presents the same trend, as shown in Figure S7 of the SI. The d-band center of the Pt42 shell, which is often used in discussion, exhibits the same trend as that by εVB-top (Fig. 7). We will investigate mainly the εVB-top in Pt55, Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42, because of two reasons; in one, orbital energy of occupied level is generally more reliable than that of unoccupied level, and in the other, the frontier orbital theory states that the highest energy occupied orbital plays an important role in determining interaction. The next task is to elucidate the reason(s) why the φVB-top exists at lower energy in Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 than in Pt55. 3.7.1 Effects of Pt-Pt distance The d-valence band energy of the Pt42 shell depends on several factors such as the PtPt distance of the Pt42 shell, CT from the M13 core to the Pt42 shell (or reverse CT) and exchange repulsion between the Pt42 shell and the M13 core. Actually, the PtPt distance has been discussed for long time as one of the important properties for determining the ORR activity of Pt-based electrocatalyst and the short PtPt distance of the Pt shell is believed to enhance the ORR activity [98–102]. Certainly, the PtPt distance of the Pt42 shell decreases following the order Pt55 > Co13@Pt42 ≈ Ni13@Pt42, as shown in Scheme 4 (A), and the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell without core decreases by 0.21 ~ 0.25 eV as the PtPt distance becomes shorter (Scheme 4 (B)); in other words, the surface PtPt distance seems to play an important role in lowering the εVB-top. However, when the sizes of the Pt42 shell and the Pt13 core of Pt55 are taken to be the same as those in Ni13@Pt42, respectively, the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell is calculated at higher energy (α; −4.89 eV, β; −4.95 eV) in such artificial Pt55 than in Ni13@Pt42 (α; −5.08 eV, β; −5.25 eV). This result suggests that the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell of M13@Pt42 is not determined only by the surface PtPt distance. Also, the lower energy of εVB-top in Ni13@Pt42 than in Co13@Pt42 is not reproduced by the εVB-top value of the Pt42 shell without core, as shown in Scheme 4 (B); indeed, the Pt42 shell without core exhibits higher energy of εVB-top when its geometry is taken to be the same as that of Ni13@Pt42 than when it is the same as that of Co13@Pt42. These results suggest that the M13 core plays an important role in determining the energy level (εVB-top) of φVB-top of the Pt42 shell. 3.7.2 Effects of charge transfer (CT) Then, we inspected the CT from the M13 core to the Pt42 shell (or reverse CT) because the εVB-top becomes lower as positive charge of the Pt42 shell increases, and vice versa. As shown in Scheme 4 (A), the Bader charges of the Co13 and Ni13 cores are much more positive than that of the Pt13 core and the Bader charge of the Pt42 shell is much more negative in Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 than in Pt55. These results indicate that CT occurs from the Co13 and Ni13 cores to the Pt42 shell more than that from the Pt13 core to the Pt42 shell. This is reasonable because the d-valence band-top energy (εVB-top) becomes higher following the order Pt13 (α; −5.44 eV, β; −5.68 eV) < Ni13 (α; −4.89 eV, β; −5.53 eV) < Co13 (α; −4.45 eV, β; −5.51 eV), where in parenthesis is εVB-top of the Pt13, Ni13 and Co13 cores; see Scheme 4 (C). This increasing order of CT is consistent with decreasing order of electronegativity Pt (2.28) > Ni (1.91) > Co (1.88), where in parenthesis is electronegativity by Pauling. Consequently, the CT increases the negative charge of the Pt42 shell of Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42, which is expected to raise the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell in Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 more than in Pt55. This trend is against the computational results showing that the εVB-top values of Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 are lower than that of Pt55. Thus, it is concluded that the CT is not responsible for the lower energy ε VB-top of Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 than that of Pt55. 3.7.3 Effects of exchange repulsion Next, we examined the exchange repulsion between the d-valence band of the M13 core and that of the Pt42 shell because it raises the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell. As well known, the exchange repulsion between the core and the shell becomes large as the overlap between the d-valence bands of the core and the shell increases. Because Co and Ni 3d orbitals are much smaller than Pt 5d orbital, as shown by the radius of maximum charge density (Rmax) of Pt 5d, Co 3d and Ni 3d orbitals in Scheme 4(C) [103], the exchange repulsion between the M13 core and the Pt42 shell is smaller than that between the Pt13 core and the Pt42 shell, leading to the presence of φVB-top at lower energy in Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 than Pt55. The above discussion is not sufficient because of the lack of clear evidence. We further investigated how much the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell changes when going from Pt55 to Ni13@Pt42, as shown in Scheme 5 . The exchange repulsion between the Pt42 shell and the M13 core depends on the size of the M13 core, the size of the Pt42 shell, and the size of valence orbitals of M atom. (1) The size effect of the M13 core is firstly discussed in the change of Pt13 L@Pt42 L → Pt13 S@Pt42 L. When the size of the Pt13 core in Pt55 is decreased to be the same size as the Ni13 core, the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell becomes lower to −5.07 eV, as shown by the change Pt13 L@Pt42 L → Pt13 S@Pt42 L in Scheme 5, where the superscripts “L” and “S” represent that the size is taken to be the same as the large (L) geometry in Pt55 and the small (S) geometry in Ni13@Pt42, respectively. In this geometry change, the distance between the Pt13 S core and the Pt42 L shell increases, because the Ni13 core is smaller than the Pt13 core, as shown in Scheme 4 (C). Consequently, the exchange repulsion between the Pt13 S shell and the Pt42 L shell decreases. On the other hand, the εVB-top (α; −4.99 eV, β; −5.36 eV) of the Pt13 S core is significantly higher than that of the original Pt13 L core (α; −5.44 eV, β; −5.68 eV) to enhance the CT from the Pt13 S core to the Pt42 L shell. This CT contributes to rise of the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell, but the εVB-top becomes lower in Pt13 S@Pt42 L. Thus, it is concluded that not the CT but the smaller exchange repulsion between the Pt13 S core and the Pt42 L shell is responsible for the lower energy εVB-top in Pt13 S@Pt42 L than in Pt13 L@Pt42 L. (2) The size effect of the Pt42 shell is then discussed in the change of Pt13 S@Pt42 L → Pt13 S@Pt42 S. When the size of the Pt42 L shell of Pt13 S@Pt42 L is decreased to be the same as that of Ni13@Pt42, the εVB-top (α; −5.64 eV, β; −5.75 eV) of the Pt42 S without the Pt13 core becomes moderately lower than that of the Pt42 L without the Pt13 core (α; −5.43 eV, β; −5.48 eV), as mentioned above and shown in Scheme 4 (B). However, the εVB-top of the Pt42 S shell in Pt13 S@Pt42 S rises to −4.82 eV, as shown by the change Pt13 S@Pt42 L → Pt13 S@Pt42 S (Scheme 5), indicating that the surface Pt-Pt distance is not important for determining the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell. In this case, the distance between the Pt13 S core and the Pt42 S shell becomes shorter in Pt13 S@Pt42 S than that between the Pt13 S core and the Pt42 L shell, because the Pt42 S shell of Ni13@Pt42 is smaller than the Pt42 L shell of Pt55. Consequently, the exchange repulsion increases to raise the εVB-top of the Pt42 S shell in Pt13 S@Pt42 S. Again, these results show that the surface PtPt distance is not the origin of the change in the εVB-top but the exchange repulsion plays important role in determining the εVB-top. (3) The size effect of d orbital is then discussed here in Pt13 S@Pt42 S and Pt13 S@Pt42 L. When the Pt13 S core in Pt13 S@Pt42 S is replaced with the Ni13 core, as shown by the change Pt13 S@Pt42 S → Ni13@Pt42 S in Scheme 5, the Pt42 S is more negatively charged in Ni13@Pt42 S (q(Pt42) = −5.12 e) than in Pt13 S@Pt42 S (q(Pt42) = −2.34 e). This means that the CT occurs from the Ni13 core to the Pt42 S shell more than that from the Pt13 S. This is reasonable because Ni is less electronegative than Pt and the Ni13 core has moderately higher energy level of εVB-top (−4.89 eV) than that (−4.99 eV) of the Pt13 S core, as mentioned above. However, the εVB-top of the Pt42 S shell in Ni13@Pt42 S becomes lower to −5.08 eV. This change is also explained by the decrease in the exchange repulsion between the Ni13 core and the Pt42 S shell, as follows: Because the Ni 3d orbital is much smaller than the Pt 5d orbital, as shown in Scheme 4 (C), the orbital overlap between the Ni13 core and the Pt42 S shell is smaller than that between the Pt13 S core and the Pt42 S shell even when the size is the same between the Pt13 S and the Ni13 cores. Consequently, the exchange repulsion becomes small in Ni13@Pt42 S, which lowers the εVB-top of Ni13@Pt42 S compared to Pt13 S@Pt42 S. This change in the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell is reverse to that expected by the CT because the Pt42 S shell is more negatively charged in Ni13@Pt42 S than in Pt13 S@Pt42 S, indicating again that not the CT but the exchange repulsion is responsible for the lower εVB-top in Ni13@Pt42 than in Pt13 S@Pt42 S. When the Pt13 S core in Pt13 S@Pt42 L (εVB-top = −5.07 eV) is replaced with the Ni13 core (Pt13 S@Pt42 L → Ni13@Pt42 L in Scheme 5), CT occurs from the Ni13 core to the Pt42 L shell more than that from the Pt13 S core, as discussed above. Though this CT is expected to raise the εVB-top of the Pt42 L shell of Ni13@Pt42 L, the εVB-top of the Pt42 L shell becomes lower to −5.23 eV in Ni13@Pt42 L than in Pt13 S@Pt42 L, as shown in Scheme 5. The decrease in εVB-top is similarly explained by the decrease in the exchange repulsion like that by the change Pt13 S@Pt42 S → Ni13@Pt42 S, because the Ni 3d orbital is smaller than the Pt 5d orbital. (4) Last, the size effect of the Pt42 shell is explored again in the change of Ni13@Pt42 L → Ni13@Pt42 S (Scheme 5). In this geometry change, the size of the Pt42 L shell in Ni13@Pt42 L is decreased to the same size as that in Ni13@Pt42. This change raises the εVB-top of the Pt42 S shell to −5.08 eV. In this geometry change, the size of the Pt42 shell becomes small, which decreases the distance between the Ni13 core and the Pt42 shell to increase the overlap of occupied orbitals between the Ni13 core and the Pt42 S shell, as shown by the change Ni13@Pt42 L ← Ni13@Pt42 S in Scheme 5. Consequently, the exchange repulsion increases to raise the εVB-top. All these results provide strong evidences showing that the exchange repulsion between the Ni13 core and the Pt42 shell plays an important role in determining the εVB-top of the Pt42 shell in Ni13@Pt42. This conclusion about the important role of exchange repulsion is consistent with the recent work showing the importance of exchange repulsion in adsorption of molecule to metal surface [104]. 3.7.4 Model calculations of Co13@Pt42 We carried out the same model calculations in the Co13@Pt42 case and found essentially the same results as those in the Ni13@Pt42 case; Scheme S1 in the SI shows the results. We skipped the same discussion of the model calculations of Co13@Pt42. In summary, it is concluded that the small exchange repulsion between the Pt42 shell and the M13 core is responsible for the lower energy φVB-top of the Pt42 shell in M13@Pt42 than in Pt55. Because the exchange repulsion depends on the overlap of occupied orbitals between the M13 core and the Pt42 shell, two factors are important: one is the size of the M13 core and the other is the size of valence orbital of the M atom [105]. Because the size of the M core depends on the atomic radius, the use of M with small atomic radius is recommended. Also, the use of 3d transition metal element is recommended, because the 3d orbital is much smaller than the 4d and 5d orbitals. Though the CT is not a main factor, the use of M bearing low energy d valence orbital is better than that of M bearing high energy d orbital. 3.8 Miscellaneous issues At the end of this work, we wish to briefly discuss other differences between Pt55 and Ni13@Pt42/Co13@Pt42. The first difference is the larger adsorption energy of O2 with Pt55 than those with Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42. Because O2 adsorption occurs with CT from metal particle to the O2 molecule, Pt55 bearing the higher energy εVB-top forms stronger O2 adsorption than Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 bearing the lower energy εVB-top. The next difference is that the OO bond cleavage of adsorbed O2 more easily occurs on Pt55 than on Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42. In this OO bond cleavage, CT occurs further from metal to O2, as shown in Table S3 in the SI. Because the φVB-top exists at higher energy in Pt55 than in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42, the CT is more strongly formed in Pt55 than in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42. Thus, Pt55 is more reactive for the OO bond cleavage than Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42. It is concluded that in these two events, the presence of high energy φVB-top is favorable. We also wish to discuss the relation between the ORR activity and the binding energy of oxygen-containing species with Pt-based particle, because the ORR catalytic activity has been discussed in terms of the binding energy of oxygen-containing species with the Pt-based particle in many works [37–55]. Though this relation has been used for understanding the catalytic activity, the reason has been unclear. Polarized covalent bond energy E cov (MA) is approximately represented by Eq. (3) on the basis of simple Hückel MO theory; [106] (3) E c o v M - A = ( ε M - ε A ) 2 + 4 β 2 where εA and εM are valence orbital energies of A and M, respectively, and β is a resonance integral. This Eq. (3) was used for explaining the bond strengths of various polarized MR bonds (M = transition metal element and R = alkyl, silyl, etc) [107–111]. Also, this Eq. has been applied to the binding energies of H, O, and OH species with Pd55, Rh55, Pt55 and Ru13@Pt42 particles, recently [86,112]. When M A bond energy is compared between Pt and M@Pt core-shell particles, A is bound with the Pt shell in both particles and therefore β differs little between the Pt and M@Pt particles. Thus, the ε M - ε A is an important factor for determining the difference in E c o v M - A value between Pt and M@Pt particles. The oxygen-containing species (A) has a valence orbital at lower energy than that of metal particle because A is much more electronegative than metal generally. This means that the higher energy φVB-top of metal particle leads to the larger ε M - ε A term and therefore the formation of stronger M A bond. In the H2O formation, the MOH and MH bonds must be broken, indicating that the reaction easily occurs when the MOH and MH bonds are weak. According to Eq. (3), the MOH and MH bonds become weaker when the φVB-top exists at lower energy. Certainly, the calculated MOH bond energy decreases following the order Pt55 OH (−3.22 eV) > Ni13@Pt42 OH (−2.91 eV) > Co13@Pt42 OH (−2.88 eV) and the MH bond energy decreases following the order Pt55 H (−3.10 eV) > Co13@Pt42 H (−2.84 eV) ~ Ni13@Pt42 H (−2.84 eV). This is explained by the fact that the φVB-top exists at higher energy in Pt55 than in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42. Thus, the H2O formation occurs more easily in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than in Pt55. In summary, (i) Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 have the lower energy φVB-top of the Pt42 shell than Pt55 does and therefore, (ii) the binding energy of oxygen-containing species with the Pt42 shell is smaller in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than in Pt55. As a result, (iii) the H2O formation occurs more easily in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 than in Pt55. Thus, the binding energy of oxygen-containing species with Pt-based electrode is useful for understanding the ORR activity when H2O formation is RDS. From the viewpoint of CT, the lower energy φVB-top of the Pt42 shell is favorable for the H2O formation, because CT occurs from H species to metal particle in the H2O formation step. The above discussion leads us to the understanding that the presence of low energy φVB-top is the origin of both the strong CT from H to Pt-based particle and the small binding energy of oxygen-containing species with Pt-based particle. 4 Conclusions In this work, we theoretically elucidated the mechanistic details of the ORR by Pt55 and M13@Pt42 (MCo and Ni) and the electronic structure and reactivity of M13@Pt42 in comparison to those of Pt55. DFT calculations show that Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 exhibit higher ORR activity with smaller ΔG° ‡ for RDS and larger onset potential than those of Pt55, which is consistent with experimental observation that Ni@Pt and Co@Pt core-shell particles are better catalyst than pure Pt particle [22,28]. In the most favorable reaction pathway when H+/e− attack occurs to particle surface, ORR occurs through (O2) → (O2)H → (O)2H → (O)(OH) → (O)(OH)(H) → (O)(H2O) → (O)(H) → (OH) → (OH)(H) → (H2O), as shown in Scheme 3. RDS is the second H2O formation (ΔG° ‡ = 1.10 eV) in the ORR by Pt55 but the second OH formation in the ORR by Co13@Pt42 (ΔG° ‡ = 0.80 eV) and Ni13@Pt42 (ΔG° ‡ = 0.66 eV). When H+/e− attack occurs to the adsorbed OH species, the H2O formation from (OH) and (H) adsorbed species is not involved in ORR. But, Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 are better catalyst than Pt55 even in this case because of their larger onset potentials. The OO bond cleavage more easily and the O2 adsorption more strongly occur on Pt55 than on Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42 because of the higher energy φVB-top of the Pt42 shell in Pt55 than in Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42. These results relate to the reason why Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 are more active than Pt55. The second H2O formation on Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 occurs more easily kinetically and thermodynamically with a smaller ΔG°‡ and more negative ΔG° than on Pt55. In this H2O formation from H and OH species, CT mainly occurs from the H atom to the metal particle. Thus, the lower energy φVB-top of the Pt42 shell in M13@Pt42 than in Pt55 is more favorable for this reaction; in other words, the φVB-top energy of the Pt42 shell in M13@Pt42 is important property for determining the ORR activity of M13@Pt42. To elucidate the reason(s) why Co13@Pt42 and Ni13@Pt42 have lower energy φVB-top than Pt55, we investigated the effects of the PtPt distance of the Pt42 shell, the CT from the M13 core to the Pt42 shell and the exchange repulsion between the Pt42 shell and the M13 core on the φVB-top energy. From careful analysis, it is clearly concluded that the smaller exchange repulsion between the Pt42 shell and the M13 core than that between the Pt42 shell and the Pt13 core is a key factor to lower the φVB-top energy of the Pt42 shell in M13@Pt42 compared to that in Pt55. This means that the smaller size of the Co13 and Ni13 cores than the Pt13 core and the smaller 3d orbitals of Ni and Co atoms than the 5d orbital of Pt atom are origins of the lower energy φVB-top of M13@Pt42 than that of Pt55. The Ni13 and Co13 cores have higher energy φVB-top than the Pt13, and therefore, CT occurs from the Ni13 and Co13 cores to the Pt42 shell more strongly than that from the Pt13 core. Though the exchange repulsion plays a more important role to determine the φVB-top energy than the CT, the high energy φVB-top of the M13 core is not good because the CT raises the φVB-top. The above discussion provides us with guideline on selecting metal element for the core; the small atomic radius of metal is good, the 3d orbital is better than the 4d and 5d orbitals, and in addition, the low energy d valence band is better. The last factor presents reasonable explanation about the difference between Ni13@Pt42 and Co13@Pt42; though Co and Ni have similar atomic radius, the Ni 3d orbital is at moderately lower energy than the Co 3d because of the larger electronegativity. As a result, the φVB-top of Ni13@Pt42 is at lower energy than that of Co13@Pt42, and therefore Ni13@Pt42 is more active than Co13@Pt42. These results also show that the d-band model is useful for understanding, explaining and predicting the ORR activity of metal particle. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) by Pt55 and core-shell M13@Pt42 (MCo or Ni) particles is explored theoretically. Rate-determining step (RDS) is the second OH formation in M13@Pt42 but the second H2O formation in Pt55. Activation energy of RDS decreases following the order Pt55 > Co13@Pt42 > Ni13@Pt42 and onset potential is larger in M13@Pt42 than in Pt55, showing M13@Pt42 is more active than Pt55. Lower energy d-valence band-top (φVB-top) of M13@Pt42 results in the higher activity of M13@Pt42 than that of Pt55, where φVB-top is the highest energy peak in d-valence band DOS. Thus, the φVB-top energy is important for ORR activity. The lower energy φVB-top of M13@Pt42 than that of Pt55 mainly arises from smaller exchange repulsion of Pt42 shell with M13 core than that with Pt13 core; smaller atomic size and d orbital size of Co and Ni than those of Pt are key factors.
coredata.dc:title: Catalysis of core-shell nanoparticle M@Pt (MCo and Ni) for oxygen reduction reaction and its electronic structure in comparison to Pt nanoparticle
